channel.title: miljko tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from miljko.

item.description: Reminded again today that the median Twitter account has intellectual rigor of a wet noodle and subtlety of a drunken luchador. Truly a wonderful place.
@pmontu33 Hope I‚Äôll be able to say the same (word for word) next year!
@TeaRespecter The whole world locked down in March https://t.co/onq4WOEr9b But you didn‚Äôt answer my question.

@GuruAnaerobic Ok, what is your (or someone else‚Äôs, I don‚Äôt care) best argument for why lockdowns in March 2020 weren‚Äôt justified ex ante? Because the only thing I‚Äôve seen so far is people using ex post (bad) or disputing the whole ex ante/ex post distinction (worse).

@TeaRespecter To clarify: are you saying that these comparisons (and let‚Äôs not go into how well they were made) can be used to assess wether or not the March 2020 lockdowns (not the later ones) were justified?
@billmceachern Hard to argue with that (and any nuances between fall 2020 versus 2021 are beyond Twitter to convey).
@TeaRespecter Yes, they are evaluating them ex post, and badly at that.
@ShlomoFelber Fooled by Randomness, Nassim Taleb, paperback edition (2005)

üìö Fooled by hindsight bias. This one is for anyone who thinks lockdowns and school closures in the spring of 2020 were a mistake. Making ex post ‚Äúpredictions‚Äù is infinitely easier than ex ante, and gives you a false sense of confidence to boot. Dangerous and stupid. https://t.co/q5yHrHQ4zy
The excerpt is from Fooled by Randomness by Nassim Taleb, paperback edition (2005).
@timtriche Not the same but close enough https://t.co/EUt8i82Klq

Several imprecisions in this essay on IRBs should not detract from its key point: social sciences don‚Äôt need IRB oversight, biomedicine needs it to be less byzantine and more transparent. Status quo is untenable. https://t.co/ovrddHZBFT
üìö Taleb the prophet, writing about cryptobros and the summer of 2022 back in the early 2000s. Financial instruments come and go but human stupidity and greed are forever. https://t.co/17Qmi2OcV8

Give a lecture once and you help a few hundred people (if you‚Äôre lucky). Post the lecture to YouTube and you help millions. 7 years later, I am yet to find a better guide to academic writing. NB: it‚Äôs good to have a live audience. https://t.co/7PhQt2RTRA
